Recommended Reason: UNESCO World Heritage Roman city, birthplace of Emperor Septimius Severus, remarkably preserved under sand
Supporting Evidence: Recent discovery of 553 silver and bronze coins, colorful mosaics from 1st-2nd century, vast unexcavated areas

Recommended Reason: Recently discovered 1,700-year-old villa with treasure cache of Roman coins and artifacts
Supporting Evidence: 2017 discovery of 553 sterercii coins, terracotta lamps, mosaics, and well-preserved Roman complex

Recommended Reason: Greek colony founded 631 BC, UNESCO World Heritage site with extensive unexcavated areas
Supporting Evidence: One of Libya's five UNESCO sites, evidence of Greek and Roman treasures, sanctuary of Apollo

Recommended Reason: Well-preserved Roman city with theatre, forum, and residential areas
Supporting Evidence: Part of Tripolitania's three cities, extensive Roman remains with potential hidden caches

Recommended Reason: UNESCO World Heritage pre-Saharan city, ancient trading post with hidden storage areas
Supporting Evidence: One of oldest pre-Saharan cities, traditional architecture concealing storage chambers

Recommended Reason: UNESCO site with prehistoric rock art from 12,000 BC to 100 AD, possible ritual deposits
Supporting Evidence: Ancient rock paintings and engravings, evidence of ceremonial activities over millennia

Recommended Reason: 2005 discovery of 30-foot colorful mosaics in Roman villa, ongoing excavations
Supporting Evidence: Mosaics depicting gladiators and warriors, well-preserved balneae with cold plunge pool

Recommended Reason: Ancient port city of Cyrene with underwater archaeological remains and coastal structures
Supporting Evidence: Important harbor for ancient trade, potential shipwrecks and coastal treasures
